content.text: Often we reason not from frequency or analogy, but by asking: **What would explain the evidence?** This is called inference to the best explanation, or abduction.

content.definition: A form of reasoning where we accept a hypothesis because it best explains the observed evidence. Also called abduction.

content.title: Abductive Reasoning
premises: The ground is wet this morning.
If it rained last night, that would explain the wet ground.
Rain is a better explanation than alternatives (sprinklers, flood, etc.).
content.conclusion: Therefore, it probably rained last night.
content.note: We infer the probable cause from its explanatory power.

content.definition: Criteria for evaluating explanations: simplicity (fewer assumptions), breadth (explains more phenomena), coherence (fits other knowledge), and fertility (predicts new observations).

symbols.name: Occam's Razor
symbols.example: One cause vs. conspiracy of factors

content.title: Scientific IBE
premises: Fossils appear in specific geological layers.
content.conclusion: The theory of evolution best explains all this evidence.
content.note: Evolution is accepted not because we observed it directly, but because it explains so much so well.

content.question: According to 'Occam's Razor,' which explanation is preferable?
options: The one with the most detail
The one with the fewest assumptions
The one that scientists agree on
content.explanation: Occam's Razor (or the principle of parsimony) says we should prefer simpler explanations - those that make fewer assumptions. If two explanations fit the evidence equally well, the simpler one is more likely to be true.
